Expectation1: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation1: Routine logs are updated on a flexible schedule, and this batch of results could be recorded later without issue.
Situation2: They hear that a community member is feeling down and occasionally check in with a kind word.
Story:
I sat at my cluttered desk, the hum of the lab equipment a familiar comfort. The latest batch of results blinked on my screen, waiting to be logged. As a scientist, I knew the importance of accuracy—every detail mattered, and I prided myself on keeping meticulous records. Still, the logs could wait until tomorrow; the schedule was flexible, and nothing urgent would be lost.

Just as I reached for my mug, my phone buzzed. A message from the church group: “Sarah’s having a rough day. Could you check in?” As a pastor, I felt the weight of their expectation—my words, even a simple text, could offer comfort. I pictured Sarah alone, maybe waiting for someone to notice.

I stared at the screen, torn. The scientist in me whispered that the data deserved my attention, that discipline was my duty. The pastor in me urged compassion, reminding me that people needed me, too. My hands hovered, uncertain, as the two parts of myself pulled in opposite directions, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
